New Records: England's highest partnership in T20 World Cups (170 runs between Jos Buttler and Alex Hales)
Key Match Events: Jos Buttler and Alex Hales' 100-run stand in 11 overs
KL Rahul falls in the second over to Chris Woakes
Rohit Sharma falls to Chris Jordan in the 4th over
Suryakumar Yadav falls to Phil Salt in the 9th over
Hardik Pandya's 63 off 33 balls in the last 4 overs
England's faultless response to India's 168, never getting a sniff in 16 overs of bowling
Pre-Game Insights: Jos Buttler acknowledged the need to know that not always do you go for a 200-run total, but also that pushing the boundaries would be to get 150 when 125-130 is considered par.
Rohit Sharma tempered the sky-high expectations, squarely taking the pressure off his players.
Both teams have had to mellow down and tailor their otherwise gung-ho batting mentality to suit the testing conditions on offer in Australia.
Post-Match Reflections: India fell short in another ICC event, despite thoroughly entertaining in the World Cup.
England bounced back from a defeat to Ireland, a washout against Australia and two backs-to-the-walls performances to reach the final.
There's one hell of a final in store on Sunday, even without India in it.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was a masterclass in T20 batting in a big chase from Jos Buttler and Alex Hales.
India hit 68 off the last 30 balls, thanks to Hardik Pandya's late pyrotechnics.
England's mini leg-spin strangle worked well, keeping Rohit and Kohli down.
Sam Curran had an excellent start, beating the outside edge of Kohli and getting an appeal for LBW against Rohit Sharma turned down.
